metadata.h1: The importance of probabilistic thinking when faced with uncertainty

all_paragraphs: 🔥 [Announcement] Before you continue reading this article, I just want to let you know that I released, a few days ago, a complete course to help you sharpen your decision making skills and get ahead of the competition.It is the result of long years of research and it is available for free for a limited time.👉 Here is the link if you want to make better decisions using a scientific approach: https://smart-decision-makers.streamlit.app/[/Announcement] 🔥
In a video published in November 2020, physician and philosopher of science Etienne Klein called for engineers to express their opinions and participate in a public debate.
As a result, I decided to take the plunge and offer a different point of view on a topic close to my heart, which is that of decision making and uncertainty.

Among the most influential people on this topic in France is the economist Philippe Silberzahn, the author of multiple articles, books and conferences in the field of effectuation and the decision-making process during uncertainty.

Despite all the respect I hold towards Philippe Silberzahn’s work surrounding effectuation, I have some strong reserves towards his approach to uncertainty, and this is what you are invited to reflect upon throughout this article.
A key theme in Philippe Silberzahn’s work is differentiating between risk and uncertainty.
Risk is considered to be part of the domain of what is known and repeatable while uncertainty concern the domain of the unknown and unpredictable.
The often given example is that of the flu compared to COVID-19.

The flu is considered to be part of the world of risk, because we have data from previous years on which we can base our decision on how many vaccines to prepare or how many hospital beds will be required each year, for example.

COVID is part of the world of uncertainty because of its unseen character, which makes it completely counter-productive according to Philippe Silberzahn to try to make even the slightest prediction in this area.
Philippe Silberzahn goes as far as suggesting that a probabilistic approach in an uncertain situation is a contradiction of terms and an epistemological error.
This distinction between risk and uncertainty is borrow from the economist Frank Knight who first mentioned it in 1921 in “Risk, Uncertainty and Profit”.

Firstly, this distinction is too simplistic when it comes to the complexity of our word. Life isn’t split into the determined and the uncertain. The two are always entangled, at all levels, and this is what forms the world as we know it.
The question is not knowing if we can or cannot trust a prediction, but rather, the real questions are:

To illustrate this, let’s look at the example of the weather. Based on all the evidence available to us, the different phenomenon’s of the weather are complex enough that we can categorise them as being part of the world of uncertainty, as defined by Knight.
As such, we attach a certain level of credibility to weather forecasts. The level of confidence we place in them is important for the first few days and then slowly falls as the date passes.

The information given by the weather forecast and how much we trust it are linked and are both essential to guide us to make decisions, ranging from the simple planning of a BBQ with our friends the following weekend to the date of a rocket take-off to launch astronauts into space.

Nassim Nicholas Taleb, author of multiple successful books dealing with uncertainty such as the “Black Swan” or “Fooled by Randomness”, who is often referenced by Philippe Silberzahn, suggests the Knight definition of uncertainty is utter madness in the 2015 publication titled “Silent Risk”.
”The entire distinction (between risk and uncertainty) is a lunacy” — Nassim Taleb in “Silent Risk”
This distinction between risk and uncertainty could have an impact on the quality of decisions.

By encouraging decision-makers to entirely abandon all probabilistic thoughts when faced with uncertainty, people’s intuition will ultimately become the only tool they have available to make a decision.

Today’s decision-makers are in a precarious situation, where they must reason with tangible arguments, give sense to things, and not just allow themselves to follow their intuition, regardless of how intelligent they are.

Remember that Albert Einstein’s intuition, one of the greatest minds of our time, lead him to reject the existence of black holes and to then do the same to the indeterminism inherent to quantum mechanics. History caused him to be wrong on these two points, both of which are now universally considered key amongst the scientific community.

When it comes to intuition, the same reasoning that we previously discussed can be applied: the question is not knowing if we can or cannot trust our intuition. The question is under which conditions can our intuition be trusted?

Nowadays, science gives a clear answer to this question thanks to the works of Daniel Kahneman, psychologist and economist and winner of the 2002 Nobel prize of economics, on the two systems of thinking and cognitive bias.

Daniel Kahneman tells us that intuition only deserves our trusts in an acceptably regular and repeatable environment which offers substantial opportunities to learn and get quick feedback. These conditions are never both present during uncertain situations.
”Intuition cannot be trusted in absence of stable regularities in the environment” — Daniel Kahneman
We can find other issues in Philippe Silberahn publications, such as the fact he references the Nassim Taleb’s Black Swan in relation to COVID-19.
The Black Swan indicates an unpredictable and rare event that, if it occurs, has consequences of a considerable and exceptional range.
In an interview with the NewYorker, Nassim Taleb was annoyed by the link made by several analysts between the Black Swan and COVID. Indeed, the pandemic we are experiencing was predictable.
Of course, it is impossible to know in advance when it was to happen. But did we really need to know WHEN in order to prepare for it?
In the same way, you don’t need to know the exact day you’re going have a car crash to take out an insurance policy.
As such, the only thing we need to know is the likelihood of an event happening in order to be able to decide how we are going to prepare for it according to our apprehension for risk.

This is how Nassim Taleb’s expression should be understood, encouraging us to invest in preparation more than prediction. He has never suggested we abandon all thought surrounding probability in highly uncertain situations, but in fact the opposite. Nassim Taleb is the author of multiple scientific publications on the mathematical tools which allow us to better grasp situations of high uncertainty.

The French state has previously anticipated other pandemics, possessing 1 billion surgical masks in 2009, but the decision was taken to pay less attention to this risk and to let the stock of masks decrease.

A huge digitalisation of small businesses could also have been part of a risk preparation plan, but all these preparation actions have a cost and our politicians made the choice to direct these budgets to other more visible emergencies.
Between 2010 and 2014, French institutes dedicated to health monitoring and preparation for health emergencies saw their budgets fall by 24%.
Another idea that often comes up is that prediction is not possible until the phenomenon in question is repeatable and that we do not have enough data from the past.

Let’s look at a counter-example to illustrate why this is not always true. Meteorologists who want to predict the likelihood that a Level 4 hurricane will reach France in the next 10 years can rely on the physical models that they already have. They will then take several global warming assumptions (from the most pessimistic to the most optimistic) and will carry out hundreds or even thousands of simulations to calculate the proportion of cases where such an event could occur. This would calculate a likelihood that could be used by decision-makers to choose the measures to be taken according to the level of risk they are willing to accept.
To navigate an uncertain world, you must adopt its language, the language of probabilities.

It is urgent that decision makers and experts are able to develop probabilistic thinking. We do not need arrogant experts announcing a third wave of COVID, but rather humble experts capable of attributing probabilities to each of their predictions, who are able to express what they know and what they do not know.

There are also calibration techniques that can train experts to reduce the distance between what they think and what they really know. A perfectly calibrated person, responding with a 90% confidence level to 10 questions, will have, on average, 9 good predictions out of 10.

The mathematician Benoît Mandelbrot, at the origin of Fractals theory, reminds us through the quotation below how probability theory can be an extraordinarily powerful and practical tool to approach the unknown and uncontrollable.

“The theory of probability is the only mathematical tool available to help map the unknown and the uncontrollable. It is fortunate that this tool, while tricky, is extraordinarily powerful and convenient.” Benoit Mandelbrot, The Fractal Geometry of Nature (1977, 1983)
This discussion about uncertainty began in the form of comments following a publication of Philippe Silberzahn. But I couldn’t develop my point of view like in an article.

In this article, I focused my attention on my areas of disagreement with Philippe Silberzahn. But this cannot hide all the agreements we may share, of which there are many. In particular all his work around effectuation and entrepreneurial thinking comes to mind.
I also share the same irritability towards the proliferation of pseudo-experts predicting everything and anything. But it is not because there are Gurus that we have to abandon medicine.
